We provide a categorical definition of quantum theory, which is shown to be equivalent to the standard axiomatization. The definition is purely categorical and does not presuppose any analytical structure. This addresses a question about the mathematical foundations of quantum theory raised in reconstruction programs such as those of von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that cause diseases in a variety of hosts, including humans. Although the evolutionary origin of myxozoans has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies and the observation that the distinctive myxozoan structure, the polar capsule, is remarkably similar to the stinging structures (nematocysts) in cnidarians. Here, we present the first genome assemblies for two myxozoans and compare them to the genome of a less reduced cnidarian parasite. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. These results have implications for understanding the origin of parasitism and the evolution of the animal kingdom. (Show more)

In this study, we describe a mechanism by which SARS-CoV-2 interferes with the antiviral action of IFN. Our results show that the viral accessory protein Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex and directly interacts with Nup98-Rae1 to impair docking of the cargo-receptor complex and disrupt nuclear import. In addition, we show that a methionine-to-arginine substitution at residue 58 impairs Orf6 binding to the Nup98-Rae1 complex and abolishes its IFN antagonistic function. All together our data unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. This study provides a better understanding of the mechanisms used by SARS-CoV-2 to evade the antiviral action of IFN and may lead to the development of new antiviral strategies. (Show more)

Hv1 channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. Sperm cells are quiescent in the male reproductive system due to Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1 channels, but become active once introduced into the low-Zn2+-concentration environment of the female reproductive tract. How Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 is not completely understood. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. Mutations of some Hv1 residues affect only Zn2+ inhibition of the voltage sensor motion, whereas mutations of other residues also affect Zn2+ inhibition of gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the dimeric Hv1. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development

The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by the middle of the 21st century, and the demand for food will increase by 70%. Meeting this challenge will require increasing yields, but also reducing the variability of yields. We show that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the variability of maize yields will increase substantially in the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries under 2 °C and 4 °C of global warming. This variability will increase the risk of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year in the top four maize-exporting countries, and it will increase the risk of international grain price spikes.

The coexistence of species in a world of limited resources is one of the most important problems in ecology. In the case of large mammalian herbivores, the challenge is to partition the limited supply of grasses in savanna ecosystems. We show that DNA metabarcoding can be used to quantify diet composition at a species level, and that this approach can be used to reveal that the degree of diet overlap between species is strongly related to the degree of dietary similarity. These results suggest that the current understanding of niche partitioning among large herbivores may be incomplete, and that the coexistence of species in savanna ecosystems may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. This may have important implications for the management of large herbivore populations.

We conducted a large survey of small businesses to understand the impact of the COVID-19 crisis on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. However, many businesses expect to survive the crisis, and many are planning to apply for government loans. We also find that many small businesses are financially fragile, with only a few weeks of cash on hand. Finally, we find that the effects of the crisis are heterogeneous, with some businesses experiencing a sharp decline in revenue and others experiencing only a small decline.

Plastic debris is one of the most visible consequences of human activities in the ocean. However, the magnitude of the problem is still unclear. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. Our observations of the size distribution of floating plastic debris point at important size-selective sinks removing millimeter-sized fragments of floating plastic on a large scale. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The origin of the solar system is one of the most important questions in astronomy. The age of the solar system is one of the most important parameters in this context. In this study, we determined the ages of 40 large silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison meteorite. The grains have ages of 3.9 ± 1.6 Ma to ∼3 ± 2 Ga before the start of the Solar System ∼4.6 Ga ago. The grains condensed in outflows of asymptotic giant branch stars <4.9 Ga ago that possibly formed during an episode of enhanced star formation ∼7 Ga ago. We estimate that the majority of the grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. This result has important implications for the origin of the solar system. View Full-Text

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has increased exponentially. The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased since the 1950s, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to increase the amount of energy available to the mother is a key factor in the success of many species. Here, we show that the practice of domestication, the practice of allonursing, and the practice of sharing resources all increase the reproductive output of mammals. We also show that the increase in reproductive output is due to an increase in the amount of energy available to the mother rather than an increase in the number of litters. Our results suggest that the ultimate factor limiting reproductive output in placental mammals is maternal metabolic power rather than resource availability. This is a fundamental insight into the evolution of mammalian reproductive strategies. It also has implications for the evolution of human reproduction.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of alpha-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in oligodendrocytes, the cells that produce myelin in the brain. In this study, we show that the inflammatory protease caspase-1, which is activated in the brain in response to inflammation, is also able to cleave α-syn at its C terminus, thereby promoting its aggregation. We also show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn aggregates in a mouse model of MSA. These results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate for the treatment of MSA. Furthermore, our results provide a proof of concept for the use of VX-765 in the treatment of synucleinopathies.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges, and the need for timely, accurate, and open data is greater than ever. We present the COVIDcast API, a data source that provides open access to many signals of COVID activity, including traditional public health surveillance signals and many auxiliary indicators of COVID activity extracted from deidentified medical claims data, massive online surveys, cell phone mobility data, and internet search trends. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. This paper provides an overview of the data and their utility, and provides examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making. We hope that the COVIDcast API will be a valuable resource for researchers, policymakers, and the public. We welcome feedback and suggestions for improvement. We also hope that the data will be useful to the many researchers who have been working to understand the pandemic.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion channels in the human body. They are involved in a wide variety of physiological processes, such as the control of heart rate and blood pressure, the regulation of neuronal excitability, and the transmission of nerve impulses. In addition, they are the main targets of drugs used in the treatment of hypertension, cardiac arrhythmias, and epilepsy. In this study, we have identified a key residue for the functional coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter in potassium channels. We have also demonstrated that the selectivity filter can be structurally collapsed by the closing of the activation gate. This structural change is a prerequisite for the lack of C-type inactivation gating and the inversion of the allosteric coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. These findings provide a structural basis for the functional coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter in potassium channels. They also open the way to the development of new drugs for the treatment of cardiovascular diseases. View Full-Text

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is influenced by the host and its environment. The role of the host in shaping the microbiome is well established, but the role of the microbiome in shaping the host is less clear. In this study, we investigate the potential of anaerobic fungi to synthesize natural products that could regulate membership within the gut microbiome. We find that anaerobic fungi synthesize a variety of natural products, including antibiotics, peptides, and polyketides, which could be used to regulate the microbiome. These results support the idea that anaerobic fungi are a source of natural products that could be used to influence the composition of the gut microbiome. This study provides a foundation for future research on the role of anaerobic fungi in the regulation of the gut microbiome.

Social dominance is a key feature of social groups, but whether personality traits may predispose individuals to a particular rank remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety directly influences social dominance in male outbred rats and identify an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders.

The design of multifunctional structures with programmable mechanical responses is highly desired for various applications. However, the use of a single material phase and heuristically developed structural patterns leads to restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, we propose a synthesis strategy of composite structures with multiple material phases and demonstrate that the structures can be digitally designed to precisely achieve arbitrary and extreme prescribed responses under large deformations. The structures are effectively manufactured via multimaterial fabrication with different elastomers and their highly nonlinear responses are physically and accurately realized in experiments. The proposed synthesis strategy can be utilized to design multifunctional structures for a wide range of applications. This work provides a new paradigm for the design of programmable mechanical devices.

The hemoglobin system is a key regulator of the timing of development and aging in vertebrates. Here we show that the IGF2BP1 protein, which is involved in the regulation of mRNA translation, is a key regulator of the timing of hemoglobin expression in humans.

Cancer is a disease of the metabolism of cells, and the development of therapies that target the metabolic pathways of cancer cells is a major focus of cancer research. In this study, we identified a mechanism of resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis that is a form of programmed cell death and a key element of the immune response to cancer. This mechanism is driven by the activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis, which protects cancer cells from ferroptosis. We also identified a mechanism of sensitivity to ferroptosis, which is driven by the activation of the SREBP1/SCD1 pathway, and we show that this pathway can be used to overcome the resistance to ferroptosis induced by the inhibition of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway. These findings have implications for the development of combination therapies for cancer. (Show more)

Hypertension is the most common cause of heart failure, and the treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of cardiovascular medicine. However, despite the widespread use of antihypertensive drugs, the mechanisms of action of many of these drugs are unknown. Here, we show that the three major classes of antihypertensive drugs, which are used in millions of patients worldwide, act on the Ca2+ signaling machinery in vascular smooth muscle cells, which is a key component of the remodeling of the vascular wall. Our findings may lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of cardiovascular diseases.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the management of 10 million hectares of federal forest land in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP has not yet been successful in reversing the decline of older-forest–associated bird species. Our results also show that the early-seral ecosystem, created as part of the NWFP, has not yet been successful in replacing the older-forest ecosystem. These findings underscore the need for continued efforts to conserve and restore older forests and the early-seral ecosystem.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a major challenge, and computational approaches are essential tools to this end. In this study, we present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. The results of this study provide a proof of concept for the rational design of new antibiotics. This approach can be extended to other antibiotic classes and to other targets of interest. The application of this strategy will help to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens and to address the global threat of antibiotic resistance. We introduce a new network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters. The proposed architecture is based on a simple idea of using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. However, the biological effects of these devices on sleep and health are unknown. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device (LE-eBook) for 1 h before bedtime suppresses melatonin secretion, reduces evening sleepiness, and phase-delays the circadian clock, with important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The YDB is a key event in the evolution of the Earth and human history. It is widely accepted that a bolide impact triggered the cooling, but the nature of the impactor and the source of the magnetic grains and microspherules are still debated. We show that the magnetic grains and microspherules are terrestrial in origin and that the impactor was terrestrial as well.

The role of CTLA-4 in the regulation of immune responses is well established, but the specific contribution of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmune diseases is not. Here, we show that the deletion of CTLA-4 in adult mice results in a variety of autoimmunity, which is not fatal, but is accompanied by a profound expansion of Treg cells. In contrast, congenital deficiency of CTLA-4 is lethal, and the resulting autoimmunity is more severe. These findings provide a better understanding of the role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies.

Beetles are the most speciose group of animals, but the origin of this diversity remains poorly understood. We show that the origin of beetles coincides with the origin of plant-feeding, and that the evolution of plant-feeding beetles was driven by the convergent acquisition of genes encoding enzymes that digest plant cell walls.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against such variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. We anticipate that our approach will be useful for the development of other protein-based therapeutics. Our work also provides a proof of concept for the application of deep learning in the optimization of other protein molecules. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of great interest to evolutionary psychologists. We report the results of a large-scale experiment that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We show that, contrary to popular belief, larger populations do not enhance CCE. We also show that the size of the population is not the only factor that affects CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results have implications for the evolution of human culture and the origins of human intelligence. They also have implications for the design of social systems, including social networks, organizations, and societies.

APOE is the strongest genetic risk factor influencing late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD) susceptibility. APOE isoform is also known to influence the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes, a process that is critical for normal brain function and is also involved in AD pathogenesis. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes, which is highly dependent on APOE isoform. We also found that APOE alleles influence the rate of C1q accumulation in hippocampus, which may represent the accumulation of senescent synapses with enhanced vulnerability to complement-mediated degeneration. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes, and they also suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 susceptibility to AD may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of C1q-coated senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration. These studies may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for AD.

The inner core is a solid sphere that is 1200 km in diameter and has a density of 12.0 g/cm3. It is the only solid sphere in the solar system. The inner core is a mystery because it is not understood how it formed. The most widely accepted model is that it formed by the solidification of the outer core, but this model has been challenged by recent studies. In this study, we show that the solidification of the outer core is not necessary for the formation of the inner core.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States, and its use is increasing among adolescents. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that the brain’s reactivity to methylphenidate (a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine) is reduced in marijuana abusers, which might contribute to their negative emotionality and addictive behaviors.

Language is the defining feature of modern humans, and the brain is the defining feature of language. Yet, despite the importance of these topics, we know surprisingly little about the brain mechanisms of language. Here, we show that the most powerful artificial neural networks in the world can predict brain activity in the human brain while it processes language. These results provide a new avenue for understanding the brain mechanisms of language.

Deep learning has been a major advance in machine learning and has led to many successful applications. However, it is still in its infancy and has not yet been used in scientific computing. We show that deep learning is not always well-conditioned, and that this is a fundamental problem that needs to be addressed before deep learning can be used in scientific computing.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including the failure of governments to act quickly enough, the failure of the pharmaceutical industry to develop a vaccine quickly enough, and the failure of the public to comply with public health measures. In this article, we argue that the failure to comply with public health measures is not only due to a lack of trust in science, but also due to a lack of understanding of exponential growth. We discuss a classic psychological experiment published 45 years ago that is often cited as evidence for this claim, but that, in fact, is based on a flawed methodology.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years, and it is still with us today. In this study, we sequenced the genome of a new leprosy pathogen, and compared it with that of the well-studied leprosy pathogen, Mycobacterium leprae. We found that the two pathogens are remarkably similar, and that they are still able to cause similar diseases.

Entanglement and entropy are the two main resources in quantum information science and the two main ingredients of the second law of thermodynamics. However, the relation between them is still not fully understood. In this work, we show that the entanglement dynamics in integrable systems can be understood in terms of quasiparticles, which are the elementary excitations of the system. This allows us to compute the entanglement dynamics in the scaling limit of the time and the distance between the initial state and the steady state. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain and find perfect agreement. This result is a milestone in the study of the relation between entanglement and thermodynamics.

The development of a vaccine against SARS-CoV-2 is a global priority. Here, we describe a vaccine candidate that is currently in clinical development. The vaccine candidate is based on a segment of the viral spike protein recoded with synonymous suboptimal codons, thereby introducing 283 silent mutations. The vaccine candidate also lacks the furin cleavage site within the viral spike protein, which is known to be important for the growth of the virus. The vaccine candidate is temperature sensitive in vitro, but robustly grows at the permissive temperature. In hamsters, the vaccine candidate is protective at a single intranasal dose, reduces lung pathology, and reduces weight loss upon challenge with wild-type virus. This, coupled with its large-scale manufacturing potential, supports its potential use in mass vaccination programs. Thus, the vaccine candidate described here has the potential to be a valuable addition to the arsenal of COVID-19 vaccines. (Show more)

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and its history is important for understanding the history of humanity. However, the history of plague is poorly understood, in part because of the difficulty of reconstructing the history of the disease. Here, we use a mathematical model to show that human ectoparasites, such as fleas and lice, were the primary vectors of plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death, in Europe. Our results challenge the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This work provides a new perspective on the history of plague and the history of humanity.

The evolution of brain size is a key topic in the study of animal cognition. However, it is not the only factor that determines the cognitive capacity of an animal. In this study, we show that the evolution of brain size is not the only factor that determines the cognitive capacity of an animal. We also show that the evolution of the brain is not only about increasing the size of the brain but also about increasing the number of neurons.

TRAP1 is a mitochondrial protein that is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal cells is not well understood. Here we show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings.

Actin filaments are the main cytoskeletal elements that are responsible for many cellular processes, such as cell migration and cell division. Actin filaments are also the main targets of the ADF/cofilin family of proteins, which are involved in many cellular processes, such as cell migration and cell division. However, the mechanism by which ADF/cofilin disassembles actin filaments is not known. Here, we show that ADF/cofilin can induce the severing of filaments in a mechanical context, which is critical for many cellular processes. Our results provide a mechanistic explanation for the role of ADF/cofilin in many cellular processes. Furthermore, our results suggest that the severing of filament networks is a general process that can be regulated by mechanical forces.

Fructose, a common sweetener found in many foods and beverages, is known to be a weaker appetite suppressant than glucose. However, the effects of fructose on brain and behavior have not been studied in the context of food cues, which are known to trigger greater brain reward responses in a fasted relative to a fed state. In addition, the effects of fructose versus glucose on hunger and desire for food and on food-seeking behavior have not been compared. Our results show that ingestion of fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the role of fructose in the development of obesity and related disorders. (PsycINFO Database Record

Madagascar is a unique island, both in terms of its biodiversity and its human history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, and we found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian ancestries. However, the distribution of these ancestries across the island shows that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, we found that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a comprehensive view of the human history of Madagascar. It will be of interest to researchers in a wide range of disciplines, including anthropology, archaeology, and ecology. It will also be of interest to the general public, as Madagascar is a popular tourist destination.

We show that people’s emotions can be influenced by the emotions of others on Facebook. This is a new way to study the spread of emotions in social networks, and it has implications for our understanding of the spread of emotions in society more generally. Our results suggest that in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people.

The presence of RNA modifications in messenger RNAs (mRNAs) is a well-established phenomenon, but the impact of these modifications on protein synthesis has not been systematically explored. Here, we show that the presence of one of the most common modifications in coding regions, pseudouridine (Ψ), can alter the rate of protein synthesis. Our results suggest that the presence of Ψ in an mRNA codon can alter the rate of protein synthesis and the decoding of the mRNA. These findings have implications for our understanding of the role of mRNA modifications in protein synthesis and the evolution of the RNA world. (Show more)

This study shows that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, stronger social relationships, and a healthier lifestyle. These associations are independent of factors such as prosperity or depressive symptoms, and they are maintained over time. The feeling that life is worthwhile may be a key factor in promoting healthy aging and sustaining social relationships at older ages.

The evolution of body size is one of the most fundamental questions in biology. Here, we show that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. This size attractor is consistent with the energetic constraints of the aquatic medium.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold, and the ability of the virus to replicate more efficiently at the cool temperatures of the nasal cavity may contribute to the severity of the disease. Here, we show that the replication of rhinovirus is temperature dependent in primary mouse airway cells, and that this temperature dependence is dependent on the MAVS protein and type I IFN. These findings may help to explain the severity of rhinovirus infections.

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a major cause of infections in humans and animals. It is a master of surface attachment and is able to form biofilms, which are the main cause of infections in medical devices and wounds. Here we show that P. aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its pili to sense surfaces and to regulate its surface-induced virulence. This is the first example of a bacterial mechanosensory system that uses pili as a sensor. Our findings have implications for the development of new antibiofilm strategies. Furthermore, they provide a mechanistic understanding of the role of pili in surface sensing and virulence.

The importance of agricultural pesticides in surface water has been underestimated due to a lack of comprehensive quantitative analysis. This study provides a global metaanalysis of the presence of pesticides in surface water and their effects on aquatic biodiversity. We show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions.

This study provides a unique perspective on the role of wildlife in the spread of SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19. The study also provides a model for the study of the ecology of emerging infectious diseases.

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major problem that is not being addressed. The problems are similar to those in the developed world, but the scale is much larger. The problems include disrupting river ecology, deforestation, losing aquatic and terrestrial biodiversity, releasing substantial greenhouse gases, displacing thousands of people, and altering people’s livelihoods plus affecting the food systems, water quality, and agriculture near them. This paper examines the problems and proposes innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) protein is the primary pathological hallmark of the disease. However, the role of Aβ in the initiation and progression of AD is still unclear. Here, we show that neurons are the major source of inflammatory factors in the brain, and that Aβ is the main driver of neuron-derived cytokines. Our results suggest that the accumulation of Aβ in the brain may be the trigger for the release of neuron-derived inflammatory factors, which in turn may contribute to the initiation and progression of AD. These findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for AD.

Chickens are one of the most important domesticated species in the world today. However, the earliest evidence for their economic exploitation is still unknown. Our faunal analysis of the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, provides the earliest evidence for the economic exploitation of chickens. The majority of the chicken bones are adult, and the sex ratio is 2:1 female to male, suggesting that the exploitation of chickens was a female-biased activity. Our survey of the Southern Levant shows a sharp increase in the frequency of chicken during the Hellenistic period. We suggest that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later.

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with a high mortality rate. Although the mechanisms involved in the development of sepsis-induced immunosuppression are well known, there are no effective therapeutic strategies to restore immune function after sepsis. Here, we show that the administration of citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, is more efficient than arginine in restoring T cell function and proliferation while reducing the expansion of Treg and MDSCs in a mouse model of sepsis. These results suggest that citrulline could be a promising therapeutic strategy for sepsis treatment.

The biomass of all living organisms is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble a census of the biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a quantitative view of the biomass of all kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all mammals combined, and that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all plants. We also highlight the historical impact of humans on the biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a quantitative view of the biomass composition of the biosphere and can be used to understand the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. View Full-Text

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in nature, such as earthquakes, avalanches, or crackling noise, in which a system adjusts its properties in order to maintain a constant rate of change of a certain quantity. SOC systems are characterized by a critical state, in which the rate of change is constant, and a state with a different rate of change. The critical state is maintained by feedback mechanisms, which are not understood. In this paper, we present a model of SOC, which is continuous in contrast to all known models. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models and their relation to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena. Our aim is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is used in many applications, including in cutting tools, in electronics, and in photonics. However, diamond is brittle and can break into pieces under mechanical stress. Here, we show that diamond can be demetallized, and its bandgap can be reduced to zero, without breaking the rules of physics. We also show that diamond can be metallized, and its bandgap can be increased to its original value, without breaking the rules of physics. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications.

This study describes the structure and antifungal activity of a unique NCR peptide, which is a member of a large family of nodule-specific peptides. The structure of the peptide was determined by NMR spectroscopy, and it was found to be largely disordered and highly dynamic. The peptide exhibited potent fungicidal activity against multiple plant fungal pathogens, including Botrytis cinerea and three Fusarium spp. It was found to bind to multiple bioactive phosphoinositides in vitro and to penetrate the fungal cell wall and membrane at discrete foci, followed by gradual loss of turgor, accumulation in the cytoplasm, and elevated levels in nucleoli of germlings. The results provide a structural basis for the antifungal activity of the peptide, and pave the way for future development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes, and it is likely that the life history of sperm is intimately linked to the female reproductive tract. However, the extent of molecular continuity between males and females is largely unknown. Here, we show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that female-derived proteins begin to associate with sperm immediately after mating, and they comprise nearly 20% of the postmating sperm proteome. These findings provide a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expand our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, by binding to the glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) receptor on the surface of platelets. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that the A1 domain in VWF can be switched from a low-force to a high-force state by force, and that this switch is important for VWF binding to platelets. The switch is reversible, and the high-force state is more stable than the low-force state. The switch is important for VWD pathophysiology. The results provide a mechanism for the effects of VWD mutations on VWF binding to platelets. The results also provide a mechanism for the effects of force on VWF binding to platelets.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is the focus of intense study. The viral component of the microbiome has been a more challenging target than the bacteriome, and the lack of a comprehensive database for human-associated viruses has hindered efforts to understand the role of viruses in human health. This study addresses this gap, and provides a resource for the community. The database is publicly available, and can be used to study the virome in a wide variety of contexts. The database is also a valuable resource for the study of viruses in human disease.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. The main reason is that the ACI is complex and difficult to be observed. Here, we introduce a new instrument, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), which can simultaneously measure aerosol and water cloud properties. The HSRL is expected to be a significant contributor to the ACI investigations. The observations obtained from the HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The origin of life is one of the most important and enigmatic events in the history of our planet. The temperature of the early Earth has been a major focus of debate, with estimates ranging from 70 to 15 °C. Here, we present a method for estimating the temperature of the early Earth based on the thermostability of enzymes reconstructed from ancient bacteria and archaea. Our results suggest that the temperature of the early Earth decreased from 70 to 15 °C over the course of geological time. This finding is consistent with previous estimates based on isotopic evidence and provides insight into the origin of life.

Ion channels are the main regulators of ion flow and are the targets of drug development. Ion channels are classified into three types based on their gating mechanisms. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel is a type-3 channel that possesses two pore gates, one for fast activation/deactivation and the other for slow inactivation/recovery. We found that the BK channel’s activation/deactivation and inactivation/recovery are state-dependent and that the extents and rates of the two processes are inversely correlated. We propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of inactivation. These findings may provide a new perspective for the study of ion channels and drug development. (Show more)

Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with 209 million cases and 465,000 deaths in 2017. The parasite, Plasmodium, uses a variety of mechanisms to invade the red blood cell (RBC) and cause disease. Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the RBC surface, increasing the tension of the cytoskeleton and reducing the bending rigidity of the membrane. These changes are required for invasion and are likely to be a general feature of invasion. This finding would suggest that invasion is a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces, and that the parasite is priming the RBC surface to facilitate invasion. This is a major change in our understanding of malaria parasite invasion. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is used in many applications, including in cutting tools, in the electronics industry, and in the construction of high-performance sensors. However, diamond is brittle and can break under mechanical stress. Here, we show that diamond can be transformed into a metal, and that the bandgap of diamond can be reduced to zero. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications.

Influenza virus is a major cause of respiratory disease, and seasonal outbreaks correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. However, the impact of humidity on host defense and disease outcome is unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low humidity increases susceptibility to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient Mx1 mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the pathogenesis of influenza virus infection and may lead to the development of new strategies for the prevention and treatment of influenza. The brain is thought to process language in a hierarchical fashion, with the most complex syntactic structures built from simpler ones. However, there is no direct evidence that the brain performs such operations. Here, we show that the brain’s activity increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases when words are merged into phrases. Our results provide evidence for a merge operation that applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. More generally, our findings suggest that the brain may be able to process language more efficiently by first grouping words into phrases.

Axin is a key component of the Wnt signaling pathway, which is involved in a wide variety of biological processes, including development, cell fate, and cell proliferation. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin in vertebrates are not only similar at the protein level but also genetically redundant. We further show that the two forms of Axin are differentially regulated at the transcriptional and proteostatic level, which confers differential responsiveness to the two forms of Axin. Such subtle features may distinguish other redundant gene pairs that are commonly found in vertebrates through gene knockout experiments.
This study provides a detailed description of a circuit that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity.

Symbiotic associations between plants and bacteria are essential for the growth of both organisms, but they can also be exploited for agricultural benefit. In this work, we have developed a system that allows the control of the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis between barley and bacteria, allowing the plant to control the nitrogen-fixing bacteria and prevent them from fixing nitrogen when the plant is not present. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work also represents a significant step forward in the development of a synthetic biology platform for the study of the control of nitrogen fixation. This article is protected by copyright. We study the effects of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon that combined remote-sensed deforestation alerts with training and incentives for community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals hear the world around them, and hearing is a fundamental sense of many animals. The auditory organs of these animals are extremely diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet they are all made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the bodies of animals. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web. We find that the wispy, wheel-shaped orb web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to capture the sound-induced air particle movements that approach the maximum physical efficiency better than the acoustic responsivity of all previously known eardrums. By sensing the motion of web threads, the spider remotely detects and localizes the source of an incoming airborne acoustic wave, such as those emitted by approaching prey or predators. By outsourcing its acoustic sensors to its web, the spider is released from body size constraints and permits the araneid spider to increase its sound-sensitive surface area enormously, up to 10,000 times greater than the spider itself. We estimate the climate and health benefits of a rapid phaseout of fossil fuel use and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources. We show that a phaseout of fossil fuels can avoid an excess mortality rate of 3.61 million per year from outdoor air pollution worldwide. This could be up to 5.55 million per year by additionally controlling nonfossil anthropogenic sources. Globally, fossil-fuel-related emissions account for about 65% of the excess mortality, and 70% of the aerosol cooling. The chemical influence of air pollution on dust contributes to the aerosol cooling. Since aerosols mask the anthropogenic rise in global temperature, removing pollution particles liberates 0.51 °C and all particles 0.73 °C warming, reaching around 2 °C over North America and Northeast Asia. We conclude that a rapid phaseout of fossil fuels and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The development of a vaccine for COVID-19 has been a global priority. In this study, we report the design of a recombinant protein that can be expressed in bacteria and can be used to construct a virus-like particle (VLP) vaccine. The VLP vaccine can be produced in large quantities, and the antibodies elicited by the vaccine can neutralize the variants of concern. This study provides a potential solution for the global access of vaccines.

This study provides evidence for the involvement of ALKALs in the development of zebrafish iridophores, pigment cells of neural crest origin. The results are important for understanding the role of ALK/ALKALS in the development of neural crest-derived tissues and for the development of zebrafish models for the study of ALK-related diseases.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and its emergence is one of the most important events in human history. However, the early history of plague is poorly understood, and the number of ancient genomes available to explore this period is too small to draw definitive conclusions. Here, we present 17 ancient Yersinia pestis genomes from 5,000 to 2,500 y BP, which provide a much larger dataset to explore the early history of plague. Our results suggest that the early history of plague was one of rapid dispersal and adaptation, and that the disease was not a single, isolated event but rather a series of events that led to the emergence of plague. These data provide a new perspective on the early history of plague and its impact on human history. View Full-Text

This work examined the role of the endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 American presidential election and Joe Biden in the 2020 American presidential election. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies. They also have implications for understanding the role of masculinity in the 2020 American presidential election.

Soil organic carbon (SOC) sequestration in agricultural systems is a critical strategy for mitigating climate change. However, the management of annual cropping systems on grassland-derived Mollisols has led to massive C losses to the atmosphere. Here, we show that soil health management practices can increase SOC storage and mineral-associated organic carbon on these soils, but the efficacy of these practices varies widely depending on the management of the preceding crop and the type of soil organic matter. These results highlight the importance of integrating livestock and perennial pastures into annual cropping systems to mitigate climate change and the need for further research to identify the most effective management practices for SOC sequestration on these soils. The death toll and economic loss resulting from the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) pandemic are stark reminders that we are vulnerable to zoonotic viral threats. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spillover and spread in humans. We validated the framework using data from a virus discovery project and public records of virus detections around the world. The resulting ranking of 887 wildlife viruses can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. We hope that SpillOver will be used to accelerate the discovery and development of tools and strategies to prevent and control future outbreaks. Nectar is the reward that most flowering plants offer to pollinators for visitation. The color of nectar is an important trait that attracts pollinators, but the mechanisms by which it is produced are poorly understood. Here, we show that the color of the red nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We identify three enzymes that are necessary or sufficient for the production of the pigment, and we show that the pigment is attractive to vertebrate pollinators. Our findings provide a mechanistic understanding of the evolution of this trait and suggest that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work also highlights the potential of the Campanulaceae family as a model for the study of vertebrate-pollinated plants.

We present a study of the genetic history of the population of southern Germany during the Early Middle Ages. Our results show that the genetic ancestry of men is mostly consistent with modern northern and central Europeans, but that the genetic ancestry of women is very heterogeneous, including signals of genetic ancestry from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, we found that women with artificial skull deformations had a genetic ancestry that suggests an origin in southeastern Europe. Finally, we found that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago.

Bats are the most diverse group of mammals and are known to be the natural hosts of coronaviruses. In 2012, a new coronavirus, Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV), caused a severe pneumonia with a high fatality rate in humans. To understand how MERS-CoV spreads to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of two bat coronaviruses, HKU4 and HKU5. Our results suggest that MERS-CoV, but not HKU4, has adapted to use human cells for efficient human cell entry, contributing to the enhanced pathogenesis of MERS-CoV in humans. These results also suggest that bat coronaviruses pose a threat to human health because of their ability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmission. Our findings provide insights into the molecular basis of MERS-CoV pathogenesis and the evolution of bat coronaviruses. They also provide a foundation for the development of a vaccine and therapeutic strategies against MERS-CoV. (Show more)

This study is a proof of concept for a new approach to pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings. We show that a simple, rapid, and cost-effective approach to pathogen surveillance can be deployed in a resource-scarce setting and provide a comprehensive picture of the pathogen landscape. This approach can be used to identify the most important pathogens, and to identify the most appropriate public health response. The origin of life is one of the most important problems in biology. In the RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules. In vitro evolution of an RNA polymerase ribozyme has led to the creation of a powerful tool for the reconstruction of RNA-based life. The improved polymerase can synthesize a variety of complex structured RNAs, including aptamers, ribozymes, and, in low yield, even tRNA. Furthermore, the polymerase can replicate nucleic acids, amplifying short RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of the PCR. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins. This work provides a new approach for the reconstruction of RNA-based life. It also provides a powerful tool for the study of the origin of life. View Full-Text

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to study the physical dynamics of five US cities and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and the proximity of the neighborhood to other attractive neighborhoods. These results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also provide a new way to study the spatial distribution of human capital and the spatial dynamics of urban change.

The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is still unclear, and the treatment is still in the stage of trial and error. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which is effective in rheumatoid arthritis, may be a potential treatment for COVID-19. The results show that tocilizumab can reduce the mortality of severe and critical COVID-19 patients, and the treatment effect is remarkable.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but at high concentrations it is toxic. The ability of fungi to regulate copper homeostasis is well established, but the existence of copper-binding analogs in fungi is not. Here we report the discovery of a copper-binding analog in Aspergillus fumigatus, which has significant antimicrobial properties. The existence of this analog in fungi suggests a role for natural products in the regulation of copper homeostasis and the mediation of interactions with competing microbes. This study provides a model for the discovery of fungal natural products and their potential roles in the regulation of metal homeostasis and interactions with competing microbes. The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary deposit on Mars is a significant discovery. The occurrence of tridymite in a sedimentary deposit on Earth is rare, and the conditions for its formation are not well understood. The discovery of tridymite in a sedimentary deposit on Mars provides a unique opportunity to study the formation of this mineral in a different environment.

Frost is one of the most common abiotic stressors of plants and animals, and its frequency is expected to increase in a warming world. However, the geographic distribution of frost events is poorly understood, and the evolutionary impact of frost on plants and animals is unknown. We show that the geographic distribution of frost events is linked to the leaf-out and leaf-freezing strategies of trees, and that the resistance strategies of trees are linked to the vulnerability of forests to frost. Our findings can help decision-makers in land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy to adapt to the changes in frost risk.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory response in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, it is not known whether these cells are required for the development of the disease itself. Here, we show that the development of colitis requires the development of Th1-like cells, which are generated from Th17 precursors. These results have implications for the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease, as they suggest that the development of Th1-like cells may be a therapeutic target.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, leading to paralysis and death. The disease is caused by mutations in genes encoding proteins involved in the metabolism of RNA and DNA, and the regulation of intracellular redox balance. We now report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living ALS patients, which can be used to study disease mechanisms and develop therapeutics. This method will enable the study of disease mechanisms and the development of therapeutics. It will also enable the rapid production of disease models for clinical trials. This will be of great benefit to ALS patients.

This study is about the role of a protein that is found in many arthropods, including ticks, in the transmission of a human pathogen. The protein is called antifreeze glycoprotein, and it is found in the saliva of many arthropods. The study shows that the protein is important for the transmission of a human pathogen, and it also shows that the protein is important for the transmission of the pathogen by the tick. Birds are one of the most successful animal groups, and the study of their evolution is fundamental to understanding the origin of modern avian traits. However, the study of the origin of the modern avian body plan has been hindered by the lack of knowledge of the early diverging members of the group. Here, we describe a new species of early bird that sheds light on the origin of the modern avian body plan.
We show that the increase in water vapor in the stratosphere with increasing temperature is a positive feedback that contributes to the overall climate sensitivity.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, from red to blue, and the pigments that give rise to these colors are also diverse. In this study, we describe a new class of proteins that bind biliverdin, a pigment that is the main constituent of the heme of hemoglobin and the prosthetic group of the enzyme biliverdin reductase. These proteins are most similar to human alpha-1-antitrypsin, but with a remarkable functional diversification. Our results present molecular and functional evidence of recurrent evolution of chlorosis, describe a biliverdin-binding protein in vertebrates, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. We also show that the presence of these proteins is a key factor in the evolution of green coloration. Our findings provide a new perspective on the evolution of color in vertebrates.

Hypoxia is a feature of many cancers, and is associated with the maintenance of cancer stem cells, which are responsible for tumor initiation and relapse. Here we show that hypoxia induces expression of ALKBH5, an m6A demethylase, which in turn increases the expression of NANOG, a gene that encodes a pluripotency factor. NANOG expression is dependent on ALKBH5 and HIF-1α and HIF-2α, and is lost upon mutation of the m6A residue in the 3′-UTR. ALKBH5 expression is therefore a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer.

The Bible is one of the most widely read books in the world. The first pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century, and the source of the parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy. This study provides a simple and objective method for identifying the animal origin of parchment. The results suggest that the use of fetal animals was not necessary to produce the first pocket Bibles.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe extinction event in the last 542 My. The age model for the extinction is critical for understanding the cause and the controls on extinction/recovery dynamics. We present a precise age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dates from volcanic ash beds. The age of the extinction is 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. The carbon cycle reorganization that preceded the extinction is punctuated by a sharp negative spike in the isotopic composition of carbonate carbon. The carbon cycle volatility persisted for ∼500 ka before a return to near preextinction values. The age model will allow a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, allowing insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion. The age model will also be critical for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. View Full-Text

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that is involved in a variety of biological processes, including circadian rhythm, cancer, and metabolism. However, the function of RORα in the intestine is not well understood. Here, we report that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We also show that RORα/HDAC3-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses, and therapeutic strategies targeting this epigenetic regulation could be beneficial to the treatment of chronic inflammatory diseases, including inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). Our study provides a better understanding of the role of RORα in the intestine and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for IBD. This article is protected by copyright. The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. In this study, we use cryo-electron microscopy to compare the structure of the spike protein in the two most common forms currently circulating in the population. We show that the D614G mutant spike is more open and may facilitate binding to the receptor, ACE2, and the subsequent structural rearrangements required for viral membrane fusion. These results may help to inform the development of vaccines and therapeutics. (Show more)

We study the existence of equilibria in repeated games with Borel-measurable payoffs. We show that, under mild assumptions, every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States, and the Black and Latino populations have experienced a disproportionate burden of COVID-19 morbidity and mortality. We estimate that the pandemic has resulted in a decline in life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006.

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry and are the starting point for the description of chemical phenomena. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms change under pressure, and we propose a new way of thinking about chemistry.

Fire is a key driver of the global carbon cycle, but the effects of climate change on fire activity are poorly understood. We show that changes in human demography can have a large effect on fire activity, and that this can have a large effect on the carbon cycle. Our results suggest that, in some regions, fire suppression may have been responsible for more warming than expected. We also show that climate change may be reducing the risk of more extreme fires, which could have a large impact on the carbon cycle and climate. Our results highlight the importance of fire in the carbon cycle and the need to better understand the effects of climate and human demography on fire regimes.

This study provides a new perspective on the role of host-derived nutrients in the regulation of the activities of symbionts in the animal gut. The study also provides a model for the study of the regulation of the activities of symbionts in the animal gut.

Text data are ubiquitous, but it is difficult to identify patterns in them. We introduce a method to identify topics in text data and represent documents as topic sequences. Our method is based on advances in machine learning and word embedding. We show that our method can identify latent patterns in a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. It can be used to identify latent patterns in many domains, including social media, news, and medical records. Our method can also be used to study the gendered nature of topics in text data. We hope that our method will be used to study a wide range of topics in the future.

The second plague pandemic, which started with the arrival of Yersinia pestis in Europe in the mid-14th century, lasted for four centuries. This period is often understood as the consequence of a single introduction of the plague bacterium into Europe, after which it spread over the continent. Our study shows that this is not the case. We find that the plague bacterium was repeatedly introduced into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our results suggest that the plague bacterium was not permanently established in Europe, but that it was periodically reintroduced into Europe, which may have contributed to the persistence of the disease.

Asteroid species are a major component of the marine food web and are important prey for a variety of predators. In the last 2 y, a disease has caused the mass mortality of these species in the Northeast Pacific Ocean. We show that the disease is caused by a virus and that the virus is present in the environment. The virus is likely to be a major cause of the mortality.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a disease with a poor prognosis, and there is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies. We show here that monoclonal antibodies targeting the IL1RAP (IL1R3) receptor can efficiently target AML stem cells in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. We also show that an antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling can suppress the proliferation of primary human AML cells. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. Furthermore, the results provide a proof of principle for the use of antibody-mediated therapies in AML. This approach may be applicable to other diseases with a high incidence of stem cell disease. Thus, the results presented here may have a significant impact on the treatment of AML and other diseases with a high incidence of stem cell disease. (Show more)

Madagascar is a unique island, both in terms of its biodiversity and its human history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, and we found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The settlement history of Madagascar is also unique, with a recent demographic growth and a sex-biased colonization of the island. Finally, we show that the genetic structure of the Malagasy population is influenced by geography, suggesting that the colonization of Madagascar happened in a nonrandom fashion. These results provide a better understanding of the human history of Madagascar and will be useful for the conservation of the island’s biodiversity. View Full-Text

While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with GlpD, the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against such variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. We anticipate that our approach will be useful for the development of other protein-based therapeutics. We show that the US Department of Agriculture (USDA) Crop Progress and Condition (CPC) survey, which is based on the subjective assessments of many crop experts, can be transformed into a continuous probabilistic variable that is robust to changes in the number of surveyors and the number of crops assessed.
