Language is a complex system that involves the integration of information over time. Here we propose a model of memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in neuronal excitability that occur during normal activity. We show that these changes in neuronal properties can be used to store information about the past, and that they can be accessed in a context-dependent manner. This model provides a neurobiological substrate for the binding of linguistic features over time and the integration of information over time in sequence processing. It also provides a mechanism for the storage of information that is not reliant on persistent activity, excitatory feedback, or synaptic plasticity. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great interest to the scientific community and the general public. However, despite decades of research, the response of soil respiration to warming remains unclear. Here, we synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, and provide a comprehensive analysis of the response of soil respiration to experimental warming. Our analysis provides limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, and demonstrates that rising global temperatures may result in regionally variable responses in soil respiration, with colder climates being considerably more responsive to increased ambient temperatures compared with warmer regions. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. This information is critical to improving our ability to predict the impact of climate change on the global carbon cycle.

The origin of life is one of the most important questions in biology. The study of the origin of plastids, the organelles that are the origin of all other organelles in the biosphere, is of particular interest because of their importance in the origin of life and their role in the evolution of life on Earth. We show that the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle leads to a relaxation of functional constraints on the plastid genome, which is accompanied by bursts of gene losses. Our findings have important implications for the origin of life and the evolution of life on Earth. View Full-Text

The results of this study have important implications for the management of water resources in SSA, which is one of the most water-scarce regions in the world. The results suggest that the risk of multiyear droughts in SSA will increase in the future, and that the severity of such droughts will depend on the future course of anthropogenic emissions. The results also highlight the importance of regional-scale studies in understanding the impact of anthropogenic climate change on extreme events.

The discovery of quasicrystals in the aftermath of the first nuclear explosion, the “Trinity test,” has been a major event in the history of science. Here, we report the discovery, in a sample of red trinitite, of a hitherto unknown composition of icosahedral quasicrystal, Si61Cu30Ca7Fe2. It represents the oldest extant anthropogenic quasicrystal currently known, with the distinctive property that its precise time of creation is indelibly etched in history.

Photosynthesis is the basis of the global biosphere, and the light-harvesting pigments are essential for the capture of solar energy. The biosynthesis of these pigments is one of the most productive biological pathways on Earth. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key feature of these pigments, has remained a mystery for more than 60 y. This paper describes the evolution of the enzymes that catalyze this reaction, and their role in the biosynthesis of the light-harvesting pigments.

Neuroinflammation is a major feature of many neurodegenerative diseases, and it is well known that neuroinflammation is associated with the severity of the disease. However, the molecular mechanisms of neuroinflammation are not fully understood. In this study, we found that neuroinflammation was reduced in both the early and later stages of experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE) in microglia/macrophage-specific ASK1 knockout mice, whereas only the later-stage neuroinflammation was ameliorated in astrocyte-specific ASK1 knockout mice. We also found that ASK1 in microglia plays a major role in generating and maintaining disease. Activated astrocytes produce key inflammatory mediators, including CCL2, that further activated and recruited microglia/macrophages, in an astrocytic ASK1-dependent manner. Astrocyte-specific analysis revealed CCL2 expression was higher in the later stage compared with the early stage, suggesting a greater proinflammatory role of astrocytes in the later stage. Our findings demonstrate cell-type–specific roles of ASK1 and suggest phase-specific ASK1-dependent glial cell interactions in EAE pathophysiology. We propose glial ASK1 as a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. (Psy

The 2012–2014 drought in California is one of the most extreme droughts in the historical record. We show that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is due to human activities.

Autism is a complex disorder with a variety of symptoms, and the etiology is not yet fully understood. In this study, we identified a common mechanism for the autism-risk genes by using a reversal-learning task in Drosophila. We found that the genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility, which was indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. Our study provides a mechanistic understanding of the autism-risk genes and may facilitate the identification of potential therapeutic targets. Furthermore, the reversal-learning task may be used as a tool for studying the behavioral phenotypes of other neuropsychiatric disorders. This study also provides a model system for studying the role of the Rac1-dependent forgetting pathway in the brain.

This work is the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date. It also highlights considerable individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. Insofar as our results make clear the pervasiveness of negativity biases on average, they help account for the tendency for audience-seeking news around the world to be predominantly negative. Insofar as our results highlight individual-level variation, however, they highlight the potential for more positive content, and suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

Mutations in ORAI1 and STIM1, the proteins that mediate store-operated Ca2+ entry (SOCE), are associated with immune dysfunction and myopathy. Here, we identify two gain-of-function mutations in STIM1 and one in ORAI1 that result in a Stormorken-like syndrome of bleeding diathesis, thrombocytopenia, and miosis. These mutations result in constitutive activation of the SOCE channel, and spontaneous bleeding accompanied by reduced numbers of thrombocytes in zebrafish embryos, recapitulating key aspects of Stormorken syndrome. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated SOCE, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the SOCE channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. The study of spreading of disease pathology is of great interest to the scientific community and the general public. In this study, we use a model of Huntington’s disease to demonstrate that the spreading of aggregates can lead to non–cell-autonomous pathology and that the release of aggregates is an important mechanism for spreading. These findings have implications for the study of spreading in other neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies.

Bats are the only mammals that can survive in caves, and they are increasingly accepted as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are not well understood. Here, we identified and characterized a protein that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus, and found that this protein has the potential to inhibit the antiviral immune response of the host and facilitate viral infection. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. The results also provide a deeper understanding of the role of the immune system in the maintenance of the bat–virus–microbe balance. This knowledge may be useful for the development of novel antiviral strategies. (Show more)

Cancer is a disease of the cell cycle, and the cell cycle is fueled by the one-carbon unit derived from the amino acid serine. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the enzyme that converts serine to the unit, and have shown that it blocks colon cancer tumor growth. We have also identified a metabolic vulnerability of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, a cancer that is notoriously resistant to treatment. These findings provide a basis for the design of a new class of cancer therapeutics.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous disease with a variety of genetic mutations in proteins that are highly aggregation prone. These proteins, including superoxide dismutase 1 (SOD1), TDP-43, and Fused in Sarcoma (FUS), are found in intracellular inclusion bodies in the brain and spinal cord of patients with ALS. We show that the inclusion bodies are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, the inclusion bodies are composed of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, but are prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. These results suggest that the inclusion bodies are a result of a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This metastable state may be a common feature of neurodegenerative diseases. Understanding the mechanisms of metastable aggregation may lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of neurodegenerative diseases. (PsycINFO Database Record

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold atoms. The photonic crystal band structures are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. We believe that the photonic crystal system will be a valuable tool for many-body physics experiments with cold atoms. Montsechia is a plant that lived and reproduced below the surface of the water, similar to Ceratophyllum. Montsechia is the oldest known aquatic angiosperm and is the sister group to Ceratophyllum. Montsechia is also the sister group to the eudicots, a position that is robustly supported in many cladistic analyses. Montsechia opens the possibility that aquatic plants were locally common at a very early stage of angiosperm evolution and that aquatic habitats may have played a major role in the diversification of some early angiosperm lineages.

The study of ancient viruses is important for understanding the evolution of viruses and the impact of viruses on human evolution. Here we present the first ancient sequences of parvovirus B19 (B19V), and we show that B19V has been associated with humans for a long time. We also show that the recombination event that formed the human-associated genotype 2 of B19V occurred ∼5 thousand years ago. These results are important for understanding the evolution of B19V and the impact of B19V on human health. View Full-Text

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that, for those with less education, pain has increased with age for each successive birth cohort, and that the increase has been greater for those born after 1950. The erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950 is reflected in the erosion of working-class pain.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. In this work, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed picture of the structure and dynamics of a key enzyme intermediate. The study highlights the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide mechanistic insight into enzyme mechanisms.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe disease with a high case fatality rate. There is a need for the development of effective antiviral treatments. Remdesivir (GS-5734) is a broad-spectrum nucleoside analog that has been shown to inhibit SARS-CoV replication in vitro and in vivo. Here, we show that prophylactic and therapeutic treatment with remdesivir in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection resulted in a strong reduction in clinical signs, viral load, and lung lesions. These data support the further development of remdesivir as a potential treatment for MERS and other coronaviruses.

This study provides a new perspective on the role of host-derived nutrients in the regulation of the activities of symbionts in the animal gut. The study also provides a model for the study of the regulation of the activities of symbionts in the animal gut.

This study shows that it is possible to reduce suspension rates in schools. The study also shows that it is possible to change teachers’ mindsets about discipline. This is a major contribution to the field, and it has implications for the future of schools and the future of children.

DNA alkylation is one of the major causes of mutagenesis and cancer. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that the transcriptional lesion bypass routes for the three EtdT lesions are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The error-free transcriptional lesion bypass route is strongly favored for the minor-groove O2-EtdT lesion. In contrast, a dominant error-prone route stemming from GMP misincorporation was observed for the major-groove O4-EtdT lesion. For the N3-EtdT lesion that disrupts base pairing, multiple transcriptional lesion bypass routes were found. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease. To infect human cells, MERS-CoV must first bind to cell receptors, and then fuse the viral envelope with the cell membrane. Here, we show that sequential cleavage of the spike protein is required for both of these steps. These findings have implications for understanding the pathogenesis of MERS-CoV, and may also be relevant to other coronaviruses.

This study provides evidence that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a cafeteria can increase sales of vegetarian meals by 40%. This is a large effect, and it is likely that the proportion of vegetarian meals could be increased further without rebound effects. The study also provides evidence that the effect of nudging meal selection is concentrated among the lowest quartile of diners, suggesting that the effect is driven by the presence of a few high-impact individuals. These results have implications for the design of interventions to increase the consumption of plant-based diets, and they suggest that the physical environment in which people make decisions may be a promising target for interventions to improve population health and the health of the environment.

Cancer is a disease of the cell surface, and the surfaceome is the interface for the cell to engage the extracellular space. Here we apply a quantitative proteomics approach to the study of the surfaceome in cancer, and find that the surfaceome is remodeled in a cell autologous fashion by oncogenes, and that the functions of the surfaceome are harmonized by common biological themes. We complement the surfaceome data with a glycoproteomics approach, and find that oncogenes induce massive changes to the glycoproteome. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is a first step toward a systems-level understanding of the cancer cell surface. View Full-Text

In the midst of the COVID-19 pandemic, many scholars and policy makers are urging the United States to expand voting-by-mail programs to safeguard the electoral process. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, vote share, or electoral outcomes. Vote-by-mail modestly increases overall average turnout rates, in line with previous estimates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

SARS-CoV-2 is the virus responsible for the COVID-19 pandemic. In this study, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is a rapidly evolving accessory protein. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface, which may be important for immune evasion. This study provides a structural basis for understanding the unique features of SARS-CoV-2, and may lead to the development of new antiviral strategies. (Show more)

Cerebral edema is a life-threatening condition, and the mechanisms of its development are not well understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats, and that this is associated with an increase in the expression of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF), CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1), aquaporin-4 (AQP4), and endothelin-1 (ET-1) in the cortex. We also show that, in cultured astrocytes, hypoxia triggers cortical release of CRF, which acts on CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in astrocytes, leading to activation of AQP4 and cerebral edema. These findings provide a mechanistic understanding of the development of cerebral edema and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. This article is protected by copyright. We live in an age of big data and complex statistical modeling. The challenge is to be able to make inferences about the data, but to do so in a way that is robust to the complexity of the modeling and the size of the data. We describe a new approach to selective inference that is needed in this era. We illustrate the approach using three examples: forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step in the treatment of vascular disorders. However, the generation of ECs is still a challenge. Here, we report the generation of endothelial cells from human fibroblasts using a single transcription factor, Ets variant 2 (ETV2). This study provides a new approach for the generation of ECs and may lead to the development of a new treatment for vascular disorders. Furthermore, the generation of ETVECs provides further understanding of human EC development induced by ETV2.

We report the discovery of a new class of ligands for the RTKs anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk). We show that these ligands are essential for the development of iridophores, the pigment-producing cells of the skin, and melanocytes, the pigment-producing cells of the eye. These findings establish a physiological link between the ligands and the RTKs and provide a basis for further exploration of the role of these receptors in the development of these tissues.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex metabolic disorder, which is characterized by insulin resistance and β-cell dysfunction. Although the role of STING in the regulation of insulin sensitivity has been extensively studied, its function in β-cells remains unknown. Herein, we found that STING is decreased in islets of db/db mice and patients with T2D, and STING deficiency in β-cells impaired glucose-stimulated insulin secretion. These data suggest a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction, which may be a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of T2D.

Influenza A viruses are the most important cause of human influenza epidemics and pandemics. The genome of the virus is segmented into eight fragments, which is an evolutionary advantage but complicates the packaging of the genome into the virion. Here, we identified a mechanism that favors the packaging of viral RNA segments that are in contact with each other. This mechanism is sequence dependent and involves a network of interactions between the viral RNA segments. The lack of conservation of this mechanism might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. Our findings provide a better understanding of the molecular mechanisms involved in the packaging of the influenza A virus genome. They also open the door to the development of new strategies for the development of influenza vaccines and antiviral drugs. (Show more)

The development of atherosclerosis is a complex process involving a variety of factors. However, the role of YAP/TAZ in the regulation of atheroprone phenotypes and the development of atherosclerosis has not been investigated. In this study, we found that YAP/TAZ are activated by disturbed flow and play a critical role in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and the progression of atherosclerosis. Our results provide a mechanistic understanding of the role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atherosclerosis and may lead to the development of a new therapeutic strategy.

Wildfires are a natural part of many ecosystems, but they can also be a threat to human life and property. In the United States, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. Although climate change has likely enabled a portion of the increase in wildfire activity, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire in the United States, and that human-started wildfires disproportionately occurred in areas where fuel moisture was higher than lightning-started fires. Actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to study the physical dynamics of five US cities and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and the proximity of the neighborhood to other attractive neighborhoods. These results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also provide a new way to study the physical geography of cities, which is an important topic in urban geography. Finally, our results have implications for the design of urban policy, as well as for the design of computer vision methods for urban studies.

Natural repellents are a sustainable alternative to chemical pesticides, but their molecular targets in arthropods are largely unknown. Here, we identified a scorpion TRP channel as a receptor of plant-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study provides a molecular target of natural repellents in arthropods, and may help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. It should also help the understanding of the arthropod–plant adaptation. View Full-Text

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with a variety of severe complications, including microcephaly and Guillain–Barré syndrome. The mechanisms of these complications are not fully understood, but the dynamics of ZIKV in the host may be important. Here we present a mathematical model of ZIKV dynamics in a primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We show that the rate of viral production is rapid, and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus is ∼5 h. We also estimate that the minimum number of virions produced by an infected cell over its lifetime is ∼5,500. Finally, we assess the effect of antiviral treatment on the dynamics of ZIKV in the host, showing that the treatment can be effective in reducing the time to undetectable plasma viral load. These results can be used to guide the design of future clinical trials. (Show more)

Coral bleaching is a well-known phenomenon that is often used as a proxy for the health of coral reefs. However, the underlying mechanisms are poorly understood. Here, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general.

The intestinal epithelium is a complex tissue that forms a barrier to the environment and regulates the absorption of nutrients, the immune response, and the prevention of systemic infections. In this study, we show that the loss of BMP signaling in the epithelium leads to the development of intestinal tumors, which in turn trigger a regenerative response in the microbiome and stimulate tumor growth. Our experiments identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Our findings may lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of intestinal tumors. They also provide a model for the study of the role of the microbiome in the regulation of the intestinal epithelium. View Full-Text

Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but the response of patients to this treatment is highly variable. In this study, we show that the expression of a type I tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor, ROR1, is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. We also show that ROR1 enhances the capacity of breast cancer cells to metastasize and to engraft Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. Finally, we show that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts with a humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody, cirmtuzumab, and chemotherapy is more effective than treatment with either alone in eradicating breast cancer PDXs. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. This study also provides a rationale for the use of cirmtuzumab in combination with chemotherapy in the treatment of patients with breast cancer. (Show more)

The start of deglaciation is marked by a rapid advance of the Laurentide and Eurasian ice sheets, changes in climate, and a shift in the location of the Southern Hemisphere westerlies. The timing of this event is controversial, with some studies placing it earlier than 18 ka, the age of the oldest ice core. Here we show that a volcanic eruption series, which we identify as the Mount Takahe eruptions, occurred at the start of deglaciation and plausibly led to stratospheric ozone depletion, which in turn caused a change in the location of the Southern Hemisphere westerlies and the onset of accelerated deglaciation. This study provides a new perspective on the timing of the start of deglaciation and the role of stratospheric ozone depletion in triggering the climate changes that led to it. View Full-Text

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. However, they are often overlooked in conservation and sustainability assessments. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. Our analysis also shows that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, and that poor and undernourished populations are particularly reliant on inland fisheries compared with marine or aquaculture sources. Our data can be used to identify regions where freshwater fisheries are most important for food security, and to prioritize conservation efforts to protect both biodiversity and the livelihoods of local communities.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes limits the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable Mo-based oxide is designed to deliver a large capacity and low potential without triggering decomposition of water. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2,000 cycles. Furthermore, hard X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy study reveals that a protective surface layer is formed at the surface of the negative electrode, by which the high-energy and durable aqueous batteries are realized with Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3

In this study, we identify a form of regeneration in the nervous system that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway. This discovery has implications for our understanding of the molecular mechanisms of regeneration in the nervous system, as well as the potential for developing new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of neurological disorders.

Recombination is the process by which the genetic material of a species is mixed up, and it is essential for the production of offspring that are healthy and fertile. In this paper, we describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant, and we find that the distribution is remarkably similar to that in yeast and in mice.

The resting state network (RSN) hypothesis has been proposed to explain the organization of the human brain, but its validity has been questioned. Here, we show that the dominant RSN in healthy subjects is topographically similar to the default mode network, but that this pattern is subordinated in Parkinson’s disease. Furthermore, we show that the dominant RSN is deactivated during task performance, and that this abnormality is partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. Finally, we show that the dominant RSN is already present in healthy subjects at the time of diagnosis in Alzheimer’s disease, and that it progresses over time. These results provide a new perspective on the organization of the human brain in health and disease.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in the long-term follow-up of the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT). In this study, we show that epigenetic DNA-methylation differences at certain loci associated with glycemia persist during metabolic memory in the blood of people with diabetes. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. They also provide a basis for future studies to investigate the role of DNA-me in the epigenetic regulation of gene expression and the potential of epigenetic therapies in diabetes.
This study provides a better understanding of the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of TNBC. Our findings may aid in the design of TNBC therapies.

Alcohol dependence is a chronic disease with a high social and economic impact. The present study shows that the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol dependence, and that some of these changes are associated with the development of gut leakiness and psychological disorders. These results suggest that the gut microbiota may be involved in the development of the gut barrier and in the behavioral disorders of alcohol dependence. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile organic compounds, which are responsible for the characteristic aroma of the fruit. The biosynthesis of these compounds is not known, and the identification of the enzymes responsible for their production is a major goal of the tomato flavor research community. Here, we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase, which catalyzes the production of a wide range of nitrogenous and aromatic volatile compounds. This work provides a major advance in our understanding of the biosynthesis of tomato flavor. (Show more)

We show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature. We also show that the sensitivity of the relationship to biodiversity is likely to increase with temperature, which will have important implications for the functioning of ecosystems in a warmer world.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure for navigation, and its neurons are thought to form a map of the local environment. However, the anatomical and functional organization of MEC is not well understood. Here, we used a new method to study the organization of MEC in freely moving mice. Our results suggest that the grid cells, which are thought to be the main neurons for navigation, are anatomically and functionally distinct from the other neurons in MEC. Flowering is a complex process, which is regulated by a variety of factors. In this study, we show that flowering of the host is required for flowering of the parasite. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness.

Parkinson’s disease is a disorder of the dopamine system of the brain and body. It is caused by degeneration of dopamine-producing neurons in the substantia nigra, a structure in the midbrain. The present study shows that the dopamine-producing neurons are also influenced by a system of neurons in the striatum, a structure in the forebrain. These neurons are not part of the classic pathway from the substantia nigra to the striatum, but are part of a system that is likely to be important in the control of movement and motivation.

We all know it when we feel it: When two people are connected, they click. But how do we know when two people are connected? We asked pairs of friends and strangers to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. For both friends and strangers, speed in response was a robust predictor of feeling connected. Conversations with faster response times felt more connected than conversations with slower response times, and within conversations, connected moments had faster response times than less-connected moments. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart and is responsible for the generation of the heartbeat. The SAN is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for the generation of the heartbeat. The SAN is a highly coordinated system that is able to adjust heart rate to meet hemodynamic demand. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a multifunctional regulator of Ca2+ dynamics in SAN cells that links SR Ca2+ store content with electrical events occurring in the plasma membrane, thereby contributing to automaticity of the SAN. These studies reveal a previously unknown role for STIM1 in the regulation of SAN function. This work provides a better understanding of the mechanisms that govern SAN function and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of cardiac arrhythmias. Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development, and its beneficial effects on plant resistance against abiotic and biotic stresses have been well documented. However, the role of Si in mediating insect herbivory has not been explored. In this study, we show that the accumulation of Si in rice leaves is enhanced by insect attack, and that this effect is mediated by the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that the interaction between Si and JA in defense against insect herbivores involves priming of JA-mediated defense responses by Si and the promotion of Si accumulation by JA. These findings provide insights into the potential of Si as a biocontrol agent against insect herbivores. (Show more)

Language is a complex system that requires the integration of information over time. Here we propose a model of memory that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. Our model provides a neurobiological substrate for the binding of linguistic features and the integration of information over time.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge due to the presence of the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells. Here, we show that DNA nanostructures can be used to deliver biomolecules across the cell wall. We demonstrate that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructures are important design parameters for plant cell internalization and corresponding gene silencing efficiency. Our work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work provides a platform for the delivery of biomolecules to plants and opens up a new avenue for the delivery of biomolecules to plants. This article is protected by copyright. Nutrient pollution is one of the greatest threats to aquatic ecosystems worldwide. In the United States, the majority of nutrient pollution comes from small, rural watersheds that drain into large water bodies. However, decades of monitoring and regulatory efforts have focused on large watersheds, leaving small watersheds largely unaddressed. We show that small watersheds can be important sources of nutrients to large water bodies, and that their nutrient loads are often high for their size. Our findings suggest that nutrient management efforts should be expanded to small watersheds to reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient pollution on valuable nearshore ecosystems.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is only available to a small fraction of the possible chemical states. We find that the dynamics of the system are biased toward states that are optimized for the environmental forcing.

The history of carbon (C) perturbation events is important for understanding the history of the Earth system and for constraining the history of the carbon cycle. Here, we present a new approach to study such events, which can be used to investigate the history of the carbon cycle and the history of the Earth system.

Certification of palm oil production is a major effort to reduce deforestation. However, the impact of certification on deforestation has not been evaluated in a way that allows for a clear assessment of its effectiveness. We show that certification is associated with a reduction in deforestation, but that the impact is small and that certification has no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. The exocytosis process is essential for the release of proteins from the endoplasmic reticulum to the plasma membrane and the recycling of endosomes. The exocytosis process is regulated by a series of proteins, and the dysfunction of the exocytosis process is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. In this study, we discovered a small molecule that inhibits the exocytosis process in both plant and human cells and enhances plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is one of the most fundamental aspects of animal biology, and the genetic basis of sex determination is a major area of study in developmental biology. In this study, we investigate the effects of multiple interacting sex determination alleles on secondary sexual characteristics in a species with polygenic sex determination. We find that the modularity of secondary sexual characteristics produced by polygenic sex determination provides context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. Our results suggest that the modularity of secondary sexual characteristics may be a general feature of polygenic sex determination.

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by two distinct, but related, forms of oxidative stress. One is the photochemical oxidation of the pigment rhodopsin, which leads to the formation of the toxic chromophore, retinal, and the formation of the antioxidant, all-trans-retinal. The other is the oxidation of the bisretinoids, which are antioxidants that are formed as a result of the photochemical oxidation of vitamin A aldehyde adducts. We show that the redox state of the retina is influenced by the intracellular redox state of the cells, and that the redox state of the retina is influenced by the redox state of the cells.

Predators are the main drivers of ecosystems, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is fundamental to understanding the structure and functioning of food webs. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end, as it is associated with the evolution of morphological and functional optimizations throughout the organism. Here we show that this is not the case in siphonophores, a group of pelagic cnidarians that use their tentacles exclusively for prey capture. We show that siphonophore specialization is linked to the evolution of morphological and functional changes in the tentacles, and that these changes are linked to the evolution of prey type. Our findings contribute to understanding the evolution of specialization and morphological diversification in predators, and the role of morphological evolution in shaping present-day food webs.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolution. The fossil record of the hominin hand between 800,000 and 1.8 My old is sparse, and the origin of the distinctive features of the modern human hand are poorly understood. Here we report the discovery of a hominin hand fossil from the Middle Pleistocene that provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived feature of the modern human hand.

Cancer is a disease of uncontrolled cell growth, and the one-carbon unit is essential for cell growth and proliferation. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the enzyme that adds the one-carbon unit to serine, and have shown that this enzyme is a targetable metabolic deficiency of colon cancer. We have also identified a metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, which is uniquely dependent upon the addition of the one-carbon unit to serine. These findings have implications for the treatment of cancer and lymphoma.

This study shows that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets, and that this impact can be mitigated by having access to natural landscapes. The results have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals.

The history of modern agriculture is the history of mechanization, with the increase in vehicle capacity leading to the expansion of agricultural land. However, the increase in vehicle weight has also led to the propagation of compaction into deeper soil layers, which may have negative effects on soil ecological functioning. We show that the increase in mechanization has led to a global increase in subsoil compaction risk, with the total area of compaction risk now exceeding 20% of arable land. This alarming trend calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a second paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants.
